children.text: [New Guide] Creating a cap table for your Seed or Series A
This is a dynamic cap table document that you can interact with or duplicate to modify and make your own. It is based on the

As you engage in fundraising for your company, it is critical to understand your cap table. A cap table helps you navigate complex scenarios and drive informed decisions in the ownership of your company, like:
How much ownership makes sense to give away?
How will existing investments (e.g. SAFEs, Convertible Notes) convert into shares?
How much will an increase to an employee stock option plan (ESOP) dilute existing shareholders?
This dynamic and easy to use guide demonstrates how to build a cap table in Decipad.

When a startup is incorporated, an initial pool of shares is created establishing the capital structure of the company.  Shares are allocated across early stakeholders (e.g founders, employees, investors, advisors, etc). This is when your cap table is simple and ownership is easier to track.
In this example, there are two founders when the company is incorporated with an initial pool of
: Edit the below input table to play with different founder share levels or add/remove founders
At this stage, your cap table is simple, founders own

If you are getting ready to raise your first equity round, you've likely hired your first employees and created an employee stock option plan (ESOP). When creating an ESOP pool, you are issuing new shares to give employees and diluting existing ownership. This results in a change to your cap table because now there are more shareholders.
Let's say you create an ESOP pool of an additional
are available or remaining to give employees.
Note: It's important to keep track of issued versus available shares in your ESOP pool. You will see why later on.
: Edit the below input table to explore different ESOP levels and see the impact on ownership.

Since you are preparing for your first equity round, you have likely raised capital from early investors on a SAFE or Convertible Note. These agreements don't technically change your cap table when executed. They affect your cap table
. Safes and notes are simply a promise that shares will be given to the investor at
when the company raises a priced round. But, it's important to keep track of these early investments and their future impact on your cap table.

make it easy to track the future impact on ownership. A post-money safe  only dilutes existing shareholders and gives the safe holder a pre-determined ownership stake that will convert in the new round.
operate differently. It's harder to know the exact, future impact on ownership. On the other hand, pre money safes dilute existing shareholders AND other pre-money safe holders.

5. Final Cap Table: How we got there
When you receive a term sheet, you can build a cap table scenario to see how it will impact ownership. There are three steps involved here:

First, the post-money safes will convert to shares. Since the the term sheet valuation is higher than the valuation caps in the safes (aka it is not a down round!), this is straight forward. The scenario that we had modeled in section 3  will take effect. Safe holders will formally receive
and officially become shareholders on the cap table.
Step 2: Calculate the increase to the ESOP pool
The math is a bit cumbersome here. We know a few things at this stage:
